titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:45. Wednesday— Fahrenheit 90.

The heat continues excessive. Charles did not go to Boston— I wrote a short Letter to my Son John; but was disqualified by the weather into idleness— Read some pages in the English Horticultural Transaction, and some pages of Waterhouse’s Junius— After dinner, between 3 and 4 O’Clock I bathed with Charles and Isaac at the Creek, and swam from wharf to wharf. It was the most inconvenient part of the day; but the tide served at no other— Towards Evening I visited my Garden and Nursery— Found two or three new Seedlings up, and at least twenty that were up Sun struck dead. I have endeavoured to shelter many with shingles— Thomas and Daniel Greenleaf were here in the Evening, as members of the Committee upon the proposed celebration of the National Independence— Notice had been left by T. Greenleaf, at the houses of G. W. Beale, and Edward Miller of this Meeting, but neither of them attended. We had Conversation upon the Report to be made next Monday Evening to our Constituents, and Mr Daniel Greenleaf expressed a wish, that I should deliver the discourse— We adjourned the Meeting till to-morrow Evening, of which Mr Daniel Greenleaf engaged to give notice to Mr Beale, and Mr Miller— Mr Gourgas and Elizabeth C. Adams were also here.
2. IV:15. Thursday— Fahrenheit 87.

Fifth day of Super Summer heat. My Thermometer was before breakfast at 87— I went into Boston with Charles— While we were going the wind came round to the Southeast, with a refreshing breeze. I paid visits to James H. Foster—John Welles, Mrs Cruft, and Joseph Hall— And at Isaac P Davis’s—but he was not at home— With Mr Welles I had much and various Conversation; and with judge Hall much upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry— Hall has all the feelings upon him of a Mason, as they are now manifesting themselves among thousands of People— He is ashamed of the Institution and yet has a deep rooted attachment to it. He speaks of it as an insignificant, harmless and foolish institution, but considers the opposition to it as factious, hypocritical, and persecuting— He finds among the Anti-Masons no characters for whom he entertains respect— He denies that he ever took any oath which he considered as incompatible with the Laws of the Land; but he does not know what the Oath of the Royal Arch degree is; and does not deny that it has been correctly stated in the Anti-Masonic Publications— He thinks the Anti-masonic excitement mischievous, hypocritical and transient; and that it will very shortly blow itself out— He thinks it the duty of every good citizen to check the Spirit, and cool the effervescence of Anti-masonry; and with that view approves the selection made by the Legislature of Senators, last week, when in every instance they chose the Masonic Candidate with the smaller number of primary votes in preference to the Anti-Masonic Candidate with the larger number— From these opinions I warmly dissented; till it was nearly half-past twelve, when I attended in the Senate chamber of the Legislature, the Semi-annual Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University— I found the Governor in the Chair and Dr Pearce of Brookline reading a Report of a Committee— It was followed by several others, which absorbed the time for about an hour; though the reading of some of them was dispensed with— There were two Vacancies in the board one, by the death of the late Chief-Justice Parker, which was supplied by the Election of the present Chief Justice Lemuel Shaw—and one by the removal of the Revd. Henry Ware junr. in whose place the Revd Convers Francis of Watertown was chosen— There was a question very debatable presented by the Report of a Committee, that the Seat at the board of the Revd. Abiel Holmes of Cambridge
was vacated in consequence of his having ceased to be the Pastor of the first Congregational Church at Cambridge— The Committee consisted of James T. Austin, N. L. Frothingham and Dr Codman of Dorchester, who dissented from the Report, and requested that Dr Holmes who was present might be heard in defence of his right to his Seat— As there was not time for this the question upon the acceptance of the Report was postponed to the next Semi-annual Meeting of the Board, with an order in the mean time to print the Report. It was past two, when the Meeting adjourned— I met there a number of my old acquaintance and friends, among whom were Judge Davis and Dr Gray of Jamaica Plains: who had received my Letter enclosing the versions of the 19th. and 104th. Psalms, upon which he made some remarks— Judge Davis mentioned to me his wish that I would deliver a Discourse to the Academy of Arts and Sciences— While I was President of the United States, the Academy passed a vote requesting me to deliver a discourse, which was then impossible. In my answer I intimated that although I could not then, I might hereafter comply with their request— But at the very first Meeting of the Academy after I ceased to be President of the United States, they chose Mr Bowditch for their President— I considered their choice as a superseding of their prior request to their President to discourse to them; and do not think it proper for me to remind them of that request or of my intimation in answer to it. I returned with Charles to Quincy to dine— After dinner visit to my Garden and Nursery— Two new Seedlings— The Sun continues his ravages, upon those already up— Edward and Mrs Everett paid us an afternoon visit— We had the corner of a Thunder gust in the Evening— Thomas Greenleaf, Daniel Greenleaf and George W. Beale met here upon the adjournment of the Committee concerning the celebration of the 4th of July— Mr Miller did not attend being on a party to Nantasket beach— The members here all urged me to deliver the Address, to which I stated my very strong objections—but said that if it could be ascertained to have been the wish of those who appointed the Committee, I would undertake it rather than disappoint the desires of the Inhabitants of my native place— Mr Thomas Greenleaf undertook to ascertain the fact and let me know to-morrow— Mr Beale said that if I should decline delivering the Address, he should be for reporting that the celebration would not be expedient.
3. IV. Friday.

The day was cooler than those which have preceded— Morning fog, followed by a clear sky, and a Westerly wind in the afternoon. Deacon Spear came with a message from Mrs Webb, the widow of Deacon Webb, living in Boston; upon which I promised to write to W. C. Greenleaf at Washington—which I did— The Deacon told me that he was sorry I had attended the Anti-masonic Convention at Boston; and said I had told him last Fall that I was not Anti-Masonic— I told him I had endeavoured to avoid taking any part in the controversy, and still wished to keep free from it; but that I thought the Masons themselves ought to abolish their Oaths their Secrets, their penalties, and their pageantries. The Deacon is a Mason and was displaced as one of the Selectmen, on that account— He complained bitterly that the Selectmen of this Town, have excluded from the list whence the Jurors are taken, all Freemasons, among whom are some of the most respectable Citizens—while they have admitted many of far inferior characters— As to the Oaths of Free Masons, he is only a Master Mason, and has taken no such Oath as that of the Royal Arch degree has been reported to be. And Doctor Harris who is a Royal Arch Mason tells him that no such Oath is taken— I said that if so there ought to be an open declaration of the order to that effect— But the truth is that
the most obnoxious part of the Royal Arch Oath, is administered in some lodges, and not in others— Charles brought me out from Boston a message from J. Bailey; that Mr Jacob Hall, and others, who proposed an Anti-masonic celebration of the 4th. of July, had enquired whether I would deliver an Address to them— Mr Bailey wished for an immediate answer, and I wrote to him, that I had engagements for the 4th. of July here at Quincy, which would not admit of my delivering an Address in Boston— After dinner I bathed and swam at the Creek, with my brother’s three younger Sons; and towards Evening rode to Noah Curtis’s, and viewed my wall upon the road at Goose Pasture— The Surveyor of highways of the Town of Braintree had notified me that the Wall had fallen into the road, and that I must cause the Stones to be taken away before next Monday— Curtis said this would be impossible, and undertook to satisfy Mr Bowditch the Surveyor, that it would be so— He said also that Charles Hubbard had determined to take the half Acre of Land for a house lot, on my Penn’s Hill Orchard, at the price which I had fixed, and would engage Mr Humphrey of Weymouth to come over and make the Survey. Returning home, I called for half an hour at my brother’s— His wife, and Son the Lieutenant are gone to Medford— Isaac H. Adams brought me some Elm Seeds which I planted in Keen pot N. 1. Garden and Nursery Sunburnt.
4. IV. Saturday— Morning fog.

Mr Whitney called on me this Morning and left with me an invitation to the Ordination of his Son, George Whitney, as Minister of the second Parish in Roxbury; at three in the afternoon— Mr Whitney asked me if I would go as a member from his Parish of the Council; to which I consented: and on the part of Doctor Gray he invited me to dine at his house before the Meeting of the Council, which is to be at 2. O’Clock, the 15th. of this Month— I mentioned to Mr Whitney the proposal for celebrating the Anniversary of our National Independence, and read to him my version of the 149th Psalm, enquiring if he thought the Choir of Singers would undertake it— He said that they would be very glad to sing it— That it was peculiarly appropriate to the occasion; and might be printed, by the publisher of the Hingham Gazette— Garden and Nursery— Seedling trees almost all perishing with the drought and Sun— Planted Althea and Apple-seeds, and Pear Cores in Keen Pot N. 1— Received a Letter from T. Fuller which I answered— After dinner I went with Charles, to Genl. Dearborn’s at Roxbury; to return his visit— Much Conversation with him upon planting, and seedling Plants. He has considerable experience, and has raised a variety of Trees, both of fruit and forest from the seeds— They are now suffering severely by the Canker-worm and the Beetle— He gives no shelter to his seedlings from the Sun; but the soil of his place is more favourable for a Nursery than mine— He has a large bed, with a great variety of Strawberries; and has hay strewed between their Rows— His Pinus Pinea plants are about a week farther advanced in vegetation than mine— He lent me Cruickshank’s practical Planter, a volume published in Scotland in 1830— We returned home at the dusk of Evening— Charles Hubbard came and told me that Mr Humphrey the Surveyor, had agreed to come and survey the Lot purchased by Hubbard of me, next Monday at 2. O’Clock. afternoon— Humphrey is a member of the Legislature from Weymouth, and engaged all the week after Monday, that being the day of the Artillery Election— I agreed to meet him on Monday— My brother’s Son the Lieutenant was here in the Evening. I barely looked into the Practical Planter, and saw there was information in it very desirable for me— I also read this Morning the Report of the Committee of the Anti-masonic Convention at Philadelphia, which sat last September, upon the murder of Morgan.
5: IV: Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney— Morning discourse from 1. Corinthians 11.29. [“]For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh damnation to himself, not discerning the Lord’s body”— Occasional, upon the Communion which he after the Service administered— The afternoon Sermon was from 2. Peter 1.5.— [“]Giving all diligence, add to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge.” After the Service Mr Whitney requested the members of the Church to remain; and read the Letter from the second Church in Roxbury inviting this Church to attend by their Pastor and two Delegates the Ordination of Mr George Whitney, on the 15th. of this Month— The Letter mentioned also the other Churches invited to attend, among which was one in New-Hampshire, one in Maine, and the Congregational Church at Baltimore. Mr Whitney then put the question whether the invitation should be accepted—then whether I should be one of the Delegates, and his brother John Whitney the other to accompany him; all which was unanimously voted— As we were returning home Mr Thomas Greenleaf told me that upon enquiry he found that a definitive Report could not conveniently be made by the Committee on the proposed celebration of the Anniversary of Independence, so early as to-morrow Evening—but that he would attend the Meeting and request a further postponement— I said I would also attend the Meeting, and he promised to call upon me at 7. O’Clock. Louisa C. Smith dined with us— Towards Evening I swam in the Creek with Charles and my three Nephews— I wrote part of the day— In the garden, one of the honey Locusts planted 7. May in Book-box N. 1. was coming up— These seeds had been three years in my closet in the pod.
6. IV. Monday— Artillery Election—

Charles dined in Boston—and came home early in the afternoon— Isaac Hull Adams went to Medford, where this evening Mr and Mrs Angier were to receive the visits of their friends. We had received earnest invitations but could not go. At noon I took a light dinner, and at two O’Clock I rode to Noah Curtis’s and there met Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth, with whom we surveyed and laid out a half Acre of ground upon my Penn’s Hill lot, which I have agreed to sell, to Charles Hobart, and upon which he intends to build a house— I plucked up and brought home with me four seedling Apple trees which were growing on the side of the high way and which I planted in my Garden. I had occupied the morning chiefly in writing— On my return home I found Dr. Abner Phelps of Boston, and Mr Farnsworth, who came as a deputation from the Anti-Masons, who said that being informed the Inhabitants of Quincy proposed to celebrate the 4th. of July, at which time I was to deliver an Address to them, it was the wish of their Constituents that the Inhabitants of Quincy and I also should consent to transfer this celebration to the Old South Church at Boston— I told them it had not yet been determined that there should be a celebration of the day at Quincy— That a Committee had been chosen by a portion of the Inhabitants to report upon the expediency of it, and in that contingency to procure an Orator— I was a member of that Committee and they were to make Report this Evening but it would not be definitive— The Committee would request an adjournment of the Meeting for a final determination— Some of the members of the Committee had intimated a wish that I should deliver the Address, and I had consented if it should be the desire of the Inhabitants of the Town and my health should permit— But I doubted whether it would be agreeable to them, to transfer the celebration to Boston; and for myself, as
I wished to deal with them in perfect candour I should be unwilling to address the Anti-Masons on the fourth of July— On that day it would be my wish to discard all feelings and acts of a partial character— Besides my participation in all the Sentiments appropriate to that day I had special motives of deep solemnity connected with it, from its being also the anniversary of my father’s death— My opinions concurred with those of the Anti-Masons, so far as to believe that the Institution of Free-Masons ought to be abolished, or its obnoxious principles discarded— But this was now a party question, and subject of very angry controversy. If it should be necessary for me to take part publicly in this controversy, I should prefer any other day for putting on the harness to the 4th. of July— Dr Phelps then expressed himself with much bitterness against the principles of Masonry; but finally said he had not expected that I should comply with their request— Mr. Farnsworth said that many of them would be disappointed— Mr Thomas Greenleaf afterwards called, and I requested him to make the Report from the Committee; thinking it advisable after the visit from the Anti-masonic deputation to avoid attending the Meeting this Evening— Mr Greenleaf promised to attend, and make the Report, and said he would call here afterwards and inform me of the result; but he did not come again this Evening.
7. IV. Tuesday— Morning and Evening fogs— Noonday clear.

Isaac Hull Adams returned from Medford, and the rest of my brother’s family. His Son the Lieutenant was here after dinner— Although I persevere as yet in the practice, of adhering to my chamber all the morning till dinner time, the hours are still so much absorbed that I make no progress either in my father’s biography or in my agricultural enquiries and dendrology— My planting experiments have proven so unsuccessful, and the difficulties of raising trees from the seed thicken so upon me that my wisest course would be to abandon my plantations to their fate— On the contrary; disappointment only stimulates— The wild Strawberry Plants which I took up from the Railway Rocks on the 29th. of October last, and set out in the Garden, are growing, and throwing out runners with great luxuriance, but have not blossomed. Price Greenleaf thinks they will not bear— This afternoon I went over to my stranger berry tree, under which I had seen a wild Strawberry in blossom— I took up two plants of it; one of them having on it a Strawberry nearly ripe: I cup them up from the Soil, with the ground in which their Roots were; and set them out in the Garden; in the same bed with the other wild Strawberries. I set out also a wild cherry seedling which I had plucked up with the root— By varying, and multiplying my experiments I still hope that some of them may succeed— The Volume lent me by General Dearborn teaches what I had thoroughly learnt before; the indispensable necessity of shelter for almost all seedlings; at least for a year, and as well from the Sun, as from the frost. I have nothing that grows like the Elms and the English Oaks at the bottom of the Garden—but the Oak is of the tribe which Cruickshank pronounces good for nothing. Having Sessile leaves— The garden and the Plants are now suffering with drought; and the heat is too oppressive to allow me to work. I am writing a third discourse upon the Declaration of Independence—to be delivered on the next fourth of July, to the Inhabitants of Quincy, if they should hold the proposed celebration: and if not, for use hereafter— To avoid repetitions of what I have said before upon the same Subject, is one of the difficulties of my present task. As I proceed, I perceive the effect of age upon the Style of composition. I know not that the influence of age upon Style has ever been observed by critics— Yet is must be discernible— Voltaire wrote his OEdipe at 18—his Agathocle at 80. Compare them together.
8. IV. Wednesday.

Mrs Adams and Charles’s wife went in to Boston; dined at Mr Frothingham’s and returned here after dinner— Charles came back to dine. I wrote all the Morning with much dissatisfaction— I cannot suppress my thoughts, and find myself constantly treading upon embers— A craven scruple, a thought which has ever three parts coward, then comes in and mutters of consequences— Shall I speak my thoughts or shall the fear of man deter me? I was bolder in youth than now— I had then consequences only to myself to dread— Others are now made responsible for my words and deeds— I wrote this morning what I must blot out, and I shall be ashamed of myself for doing so— Deacon Spear was here this afternoon, and left me a minute of Mrs. Webb’s demand— He said it was time for us to begin to repent for we were approaching to the end of the seven years of plenty. This was the fourth successive Season of superabundant crops, and now the grass was so thick that it would be good for nothing— Even last year he knew a man who was obliged to pay for having the grass cut down and carried away from his Salt Meadow— With all this my seedlings in the garden, are perishing by the heat of the Sun, and for want of rain— I walked down to Mount Wollaston— Three fourths of my apple-hills are yet barren— The Chesnut trees have come up in the border beyond expectation. The Oaks are far less numerous— The Shagbarks very few, but more of them may be expected. They almost all look healthy, though surrounded and overshadowed by thick grass— This is now their only preservation from the Sun, and I hope will prove effective through the Summer. My layers of Straw in the garden have in a great measure failed— They smother the Plants— My brother was here this Evening— I read in the practical Planter, the account of Sir Henry Steuarts’ Method of transplanting large Trees—but this will never be of use to me— Received a Note from Dr. Gray of Jamaica Plains; with a Sermon of his own, and his Son’s Poem upon Change, and Genl. Dearborn’s Centennial Discourse.
9. IV. Thursday.

I answered Dr Gray’s Note, and continued to write upon the Declaration of Independence— There is more lack of Discretion than of Matter. Mr T. Greenleaf and Mr Beale called as they were going to the adjourned Meeting for the 4th. of July celebration— It moves on heavily; and is likely to be disconcerted by the dissensions of the Masonic and Anti Masonic Parties— My brother and his wife were here in the Evening— I read this afternoon in the practical Planter, the author of which is a Forester, of the Earl of Fife in Scotland— It is evident from this book that planting is as much an Art as that of gardening, but it leaves me little to expect from my Plantations— The book begins with introductory remarks upon the advantages of planting; and errors generally committed in the cultivation of wood— As to the advantages of planting, I have so long been convinced of them that no argument was necessary for me— The neglect of it, as far as I know more universal here than in Scotland— We are still occupied here with the extirpation much more than with the cultivation of wood— In treating of the errors in this cultivation the first principle laid down is that Nothing is more essential to success in planting, than a proper adaptation of Trees to the Soil— The second is to adapt the cultivation to the Nature of the Tree— The third is economy of expence— Then pruning and thinning—but he cautions especially against pruning the fir— Advises the Scotch planters not too implicitly to trust more Southern writers upon planting and contests some of the directions given by Pontey and in Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of gardening— Loudon for instance says that the seeds of the Spruce, Larch and Scots fir should be covered half an inch deep. He says a quarter of an inch is amply sufficient. And adds that the Seeds of every kind of trees should
be covered much less sparingly in proportion to their size than those of kitchen vegetables. He also earnestly dissuades from forcing of Earth, in the Nursery—that is from bringing mould from a distance to enrich the soil— This in a Nursery Should be land suitable for the production of a crop of Corn; and it is a fundamental rule that young trees should be brought up in a Nursery as hardy as possible— The first Chapter is a list of the Trees whose culture is described in the work— There are 19. all forest trees—but the Chesnut and Hazel may be reckoned also among the fruit Trees— The second Chapter Treats of the Nursery and saving of Seeds.
10. IV. Friday.

I went to Boston this Morning with Charles, and called at the lodgings of Mr Shepherd; but he was gone to New-York— Then at judge Davis’s, and sat an hour in conversation with him. He shewed me a Portrait of Prince the Chronologist; and spoke of the Diplomatic Compilation of the Correspondence of our Ministers abroad during the Revolutionary War, recently published by Jared Sparks— I spoke with indignation of Sparks’s breach of trust in polluting this publication with his own passions and prejudices in the form of Notes; paltering with truth; and distorting facts to suit his own views— Judge Davis Spoke also of the one year’s annuity upon one of W. N. Boylston’s benefactions to Harvard College, which the Judge says was not paid, though Mr Boylston thought it was: and for which the judge as Treasurer of the College has been held responsible. I went next to Charles’s Office, and there met P. P. F. Degrand: who has made the arrangements for a loan which I propose to make for six Months from the 21st. of this Month— Mr Timothy Fuller came afterwards to the Office, and it was to meet him at his request that I went to the City— He said that since my attendance at the Antimasonic Convention in Boston, he had been questioned how far it might be considered as pledging me in opposition to the Election of Mr. Clay as President of the United States— I said that Mr Clay’s election did not enter into my Consideration at all as connected with this subject— I did not propose to take any part in the next Presidential Election— I did not know whether Mr Clay would be supported by the Anti-Masons or not— They were to hold a Convention at Baltimore next September to determine upon this question— If they should fix upon another Candidate than Mr Clay, it would be an incident in no wise essential to the principle— The dissolution of the Masonic Institution in the United States, I believe to be vastly more important to us and our Posterity, than the question whether Mr Clay or General Jackson shall be the President chosen at the next Election— Mr Fuller said he was satisfied with this answer— He avowed that for himself he had no partiality in favour of Mr Clay, and intimated that his preference was for Judge M’lean of Ohio—but that others favoured Mr Rush— I told him of the application made to me by the Committee from the Anti-Masonics in Boston, to deliver an Address to them on the 4th. of July which I had declined—of which he said he was glad: but he asked if I had any objection to the publication of that part of my Letter to him which expressed the opinion that the Institution ought to be dissolved; or to discard their Secrets, Oaths, Penalties and Pageantries— I declined for the present the publication of any part of my Letter— Our conversation was interrupted, and I had not the opportunity to say much of what I intended— Mr Nathaniel Curtis brought a Letter he had just received from Petty Vaughan, asking for favours but indicating no prospect of his fidelity to his trust. He spoke of some other transactions relating to the Execution of W. N. Boylston’s Will, and said John Boylston had given up the large farm at Princeton which had now a Tenant at the halves— I proposed to him to pay to the Treasurer of Harvard College the year’s Annuity, which appears to be in arrear, which he said he
he would do— He thought a new account might be settled with the judge of Probate next August; and that Ward Boylston would be prepared to enter at the University this year— I returned with Charles to Quincy to dine— The heat of the weather excessive. In the Evening we had a party to Mr John Angier and his bride, who came from Medford. My brother and all his family, with two Misses Harrod, Susan and Mary, Miss Apthorp Mrs Baxter and two daughters, G. W. Beale; Revd. Andrew and Mrs Bigelow, Mrs Mary Dawes Mrs A. H. and Mrs Edward Everett. J. M. Gourgas, Thomas Greenleaf and his two Daughters, Daniel and Mrs Greenleaf, John Marston, Edward Miller Revd. Mr Potter, Louisa C. Smith Mr Peter and Mrs Whitney and their daughter Caroline, and Dr Woodward here— Much other company of the neighbourhood were invited but came not— Mr Thomas Greenleaf told me that he, with Daniel Greenleaf and G. W. Beale had been here this Morning, to invite me to deliver the Address on the fourth of July— It had been finally determined that the celebration should be held and a Committee of Arrangements was chosen at the Meeting last Evening.
11. V. Saturday.

Bath at the Creek, and swam from wharf to wharf. Charles and Isaac went in below. Charles Hobart came for his deed— I called on Thomas Greenleaf and at my request he came to my house and took the acknowledgment of my wife and myself— I delivered the Deed, and received payment— The drought and heat continue; but as the Spring tide of the new Moon came in, it brought with it an easterly breeze which refreshed and cooled the atmosphere— I brought over from the Hills two plants of the wild Strawberry, and set them out in my garden; and planted a dozen Strawberries with the seeds, in white Pot N. 1— My new seedlings in the Nursery perish daily— All the pears and most of the Apples are gone. The Horse Chesnuts shrink up— The peaches and Wild Cherries bear the Sun apparently without suffering— A new tree shewed itself in the Garden— And one or two in the Nursery— My beetle-bitten grey Oak, is throwing out new shoots— In the chapter on the Nursery my practical Planter recommends an average soil; not much exposed—not at all sheltered says that Seedlings must attain a certain size to stand the winter— That covering with beds of Straw always damages the Plants; and that in thin Soils the drought of Summer causes them to go off by thousands soon after they make their appearance— Perennial weeds must be completely eradicated. It should be sown with Turneps— Moderately manured with dung, and also with lime— The ground should be trenched and ridged before Winter: and sown or planted generally in March or April— Transplantation should also be performed in the Spring; before the plants begin to vegetate— Cuttings should be planted in February or earlier— Weeding should be performed by the hand, and all young trees should be pruned. Seeds should not be gathered till perfectly ripe— The Seeds of Oak and beech are seldom saved. The third Chapter is upon the purchasing of Plants— The fourth on the qualities of the soil suited to the varieties of forest trees— Strong clay is the best Soil for Oaks—
12. IV. Sunday— Sun rose 4:28.

Heard Mr Parkman of Boston, from Exodus 20.5. “For I, the Lord thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth Generation, of them that hate me; 6. and shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me and keep my Commandments[”]— The attribution of human Passions, and especially of so vicious a Passion as Jealousy, to the
Creator of the world, and the Justice of the declaration that the iniquity of the fathers shall be visited upon the children to the third and fourth Generation, are difficulties in this text which Mr Parkman endeavoured to resolve— With regard to the ascription of Jealousy to God, he considered it as only an accommodation of the language to the understanding of men; and he shewed first that the visitation of the iniquity of Parents upon their posterity was conformable to all the Analogies of Nature—but secondly that the Law itself was adapted to the circumstances of the Hebrew Nation at that time— Not universal to all Mankind—nor even permanently to the Mosaic dispensation itself. In proof of which he cited the 18th. chapter of Ezekiel; and especially the 20th. verse— “The Soul that sinneth it shall die. The son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, neither shall the father bear the iniquity of the Son: the righteousness of the righteous shall be upon him, and the wickedness of the wicked shall be upon him”— This is clear and explicit; and the whole chapter is a minute developement of the principle— But the book of Ezekiel, was held of doubtful authenticity by the Jews on account of this very chapter— That in the dispensations of Providence children almost universally do suffer for the iniquity of the fathers is certain— There is perhaps one way of reconciling the precept of the Mosaic Law, with the apparently contradictory exposition of the prophet. The promise of exemption to the child from punishment for the iniquity of the father, is an condition not only that he shall forsake the Sin of his father: but shall atone for it by his own righteousness— In the 33d. chapter of Ezekiel, the same promise of pardon and exemption from punishment is made to the wicked man himself, on condition of his turning from his iniquity by righteousness— This is the Law of Justice and of Mercy— Mr Parkman dined with us—and my brother and Louisa C. Smith. The afternoon text was from 2. Chronicles— Towards Evening I visited my garden and Nursery but the heat has brought upon me a fit of helpless indolence— The prospects of a shower were dispersed, the Evening almost cold; and the plants of the garden scorching to death.
13. IV Monday. Sun rose 4.28.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Immediately after dinner I bathed at the wharf with Isaac H. Adams, and the wind blowing fresh, lost my drawers which must have blown into the Creek— I rode with the Ladies to Braintree and stopp’d at Solomon Thayers, but he was not at home— I wished to make enquiries about the crop of Oats or of Leghorn wheat, the seed of which I had from him two years ago— Mine sown in the Nursery is now nearly ripe, and I wished to consult him as to the time for reaping it— His wife said not till the last of July; but it is suffering with the drought— There was a patch of the grain growing in his Garden which appeared less advanced than mine— Lieutt. T. B. Adams was here this Evening. He is going to-morrow for New-York and West Point— Reading the Practical Planter— Chapter 5. contains directions for ascertaining the Quality of waste Land from the Nature of the wild Plants that grow upon it— These directions are all adapted to the Soil of Scotland; and their exemplifications can be of no possible use to us here. The grey moss, benty grass, heath, furze and broom, fern and jumper are most if not all of them Strangers here; but the principle is to be observed, and the plantation of Trees must always be adapted to the nature of the Soil where they are to grow. All needle wood, and the Oak is suited to dry land— The Ash, beech and elm, require a rich soil. Many Mineral productions are unfavourable to the growth of timber, and few kinds of trees will grow where Slate abounds. Freestone near the surface is inimical to the production of wood—but not limestone, or granite— Chapter 6. is on the planting of waste Land— Section 1. Preparation of the ground for the reception of the Plants.— Enclosing—ditching— Sometimes ploughing— Section 2 Of the Age which the different kinds of trees should be when removed from the Nursery to the Waste Land— Firs, Larches, and Spruce should be two years old. But the deciduous trees Ash, beech, elm and plane should be two years in the seed bed, and then two
years in the Nursery, before removal— Oaks should never be transplanted— Description of the two modes of planting by Pitting and notching— Section 3. Season of planting—distances and order of Plants— Roads in Plantations— Planting should be done from the middle of October to the middle of March— Autumnal planting not till the wood is ripened; and Spring planting not after the buds begin to swell— Trees should be planted thick— Three or four thousand to an Acre—to shelter, and support one another, and to be thinned, when eight or ten years old, but deciduous trees to remain till large in the Nursery should be from sixteen to twenty-five or thirty feet asunder, with firs between them for Nurses— Trees should not be planted in straight lines; the appearance of which is stiff and formal: and it makes a thoroughfare for the wind between the rows— Roads, not straight should give access to every part of the Plantation— Section 4. Supplementary Remarks— Shelter for deciduous trees. Firs recommended—to be planted several years before the trees they are to shelter. (A new seedling up in book box fronting the window—)
14. IV. Tuesday.

We had morning visits from Mr Brooks, Mr and Mrs Frothingham; and Mrs P. C. Brooks junr— At length after near three weeks of extreme daily heat, and a withering Sun, we had this day a succession of Showers; light in the Morning, and very copious in the afternoon and Evening— It relieves my Garden and Nursery; and may save some of my perishing Seedlings— St. Evremont charmed with the panegyrics of the Poets on rural life, removed from the noise and turbulence of the City; and took a house in the Country— Within three days a Pigeon deserted or was stolen from his dove-cote [“]et me voila au des espoir pour la perte d’un Pigeon”— So said the philosopher St. Evremont, and quickly moved back to the City, so that if he must be unhappy; the causes of his distress might have some substance and dignity— This Story made a deep impression upon my mind when I read it; but there are little cares and anxieties in the City as well as in the Country; and great ones in the Country as well as in the City— My plantations are a source of amusement to me; and to my friends at my expense— They afford me exercise, and contribute to my health—but they absorb an unreasonable portion of my time, and engage too much of my sensibility— I finished this day the first writing of my proposed Address for the 4th. of July with a mortified conviction of its inferiority to both my former discourses on the same occasion— I feel the decay of all my Powers— Imagination, Memory, and even Judgment— It is the course of Nature, and the Will of Heaven— Why should I complain? I wrote also to my Son John, and read in the Practical Planter— Chapter 7. on the Management of Woods— Section 1. Deciduous trees should be pruned; but not the fir or the Larch— Pontey holds that firs should be pruned; a great error. Of other trees all the lateral branches should be cropped which threaten to outgrow the leader and no others— Pruning should be repeated every two years, while the tree is growing, but no longer— Section 2. Thinning— This must be commenced as soon as the branches of the Trees begin to interfere with one another. They must be planted thick to yield mutual shelter, and gradually thinned to avoid mutual collision. The thinning and pruning should be effected while the plants and branches are young and tender to avoid the use of the Saw. Chapter 8. on the culture and management of the Oak— This is the kernel of the whole work. Section 1. is an argument to refute the prevailing opinion that the Soil and Climate of Scotland are not suited to the production of the Oak— His main position is that in
former Ages the Oak did grow in great profusion without cultivation, and he attributes to defective cultivation, all the failures to raise it in modern times— Section 2. is on the defects and errors of the common method of propagating Oak— The first of which is transplanting it at-all— It is a tap-rooted plant, and all such inevitably suffer by transplantation— The second is the mode of planting and transplanting the Oak, in Scotland which is described and censured— The third is neglect of thinning and pruning— Section 3. describes the new Method of rearing Oak invented by the author of the book—of which more hereafter.
15. IV:30. Wednesday.

I went with Isaac H. Adams to Roxbury—dined at Dr Thomas Gray’s; where were Mr Peter Whitney his three Sons, and two daughters— Dr Gray’s two Sons, and daughter, George Whitney’s wife—a nephew of Dr Gray’s and a Mr Dabney— Dr Gray lent me copies of a manuscript correspondence between Timothy Pickering and Thomas Jefferson upon the Christian Religion, of which I had never heard till he mentioned it to me— Immediately after dinner we went to Swallow’s tavern, where at 2. O’Clock the Council was held for the Ordination of Mr George Whitney to the Pastoral Charge of the second Parish in Roxbury— Dr Thaddeus Mason Harris my Classmate was chosen Moderator of the Council; and Mr Putnam the Colleague of Dr Porter of Roxbury, Scribe—a List of the invited Churches was called over, and a minute recorded of those which attended by their Pastors and Delegates— I attended as one of the Delegates of the Church at Quincy— One of the Members of the second Church of Roxbury attended with the Book of Church Records— The unanimous invitation of the Society, to Mr George Whitney, to become their Pastor was stated, and his answer of acceptance was read— A resolution was then adopted that the Council were ready to proceed to the Ordination; and the parts of Performance were assigned by vote, as they had been previously arranged by the Committee of the Parish— At three O’Clock we proceeded to the Church— The services began by singing of an Anthem— The Introductory Prayer was made by Mr Putnam— Selections from Scripture were then read by Mr Hedge of West-Cambridge— Watts’s Hymn “How beauteous are their feet” was sung. The Sermon was preached by Mr Peter Whitney from Revelations.

Then followed an Original hymn, by Dr Thomas Gray junr. The ordaining prayer by Dr Lowell—the Charge by the Revd. Dr Gray— The right-hand of fellowship by Mr Barlow, and a hymn also composed by him— An Address to the Society by Mr Pierpont— Concluding prayer by Mr Lamson—an Anthem— And the Benediction by Mr. George Whitney. The most remarkable part of the performance was the right hand of fellowship, by David Hatch Barlow a Classmate of George Whitney’s and now settled at Lynn— The address to the Society by Mr Pierpont was an Admonition rather sharp to the People of the Parish of what they would have no right to require of their Pastor— After the ceremonies were concluded the Council returned to the Tavern, where there was a light Supper— We returned to Quincy and reached home about eight O’Clock— It rained steadily all the time we were on the way to Roxbury; and profusely during the whole time of the Ceremonies at the Meeting House— Charles brought me yesterday a Volume belonging to the Athenaeum containing James Otis’s Rights of the British Colonies asserted and proved—originally published 23. July 1764— Reprinted in London 1766. In this pamphlet page 49. He lays it down as a first principle that the Colonies are subject to and dependent on Great-Britain, and therefore that Parliament has a right to make laws to bind them, equally as upon the Subjects of Great-Britain within the realm.
16. IV. Thursday.— Fog and Rain

Showery day— Price Greenleaf was here after dinner— The rain has brought up a forest of weeds in my Nursery; but little relief to my Seedlings; and the appearance of only two or three new ones— I planted a few cherry Stones, of the Kentish Cherry now in the Garden; and placed them between the Suckers taken up and set out from my Mazzard below— There are now in the garden and Nursery six different Seedling trees up, which I do not know— Rosebugs, Slugworms and Caterpillars depredate upon the leaves of many. The Peaches and Wild-Cherries have best stood the ordeal of the Sun beam. My wild Strawberries grow and spread profusely but put forth no blossom. Charles did not go to Boston— Towards Evening I walked to my brother’s. His daughter Elizabeth came in from Medford with Mr Gourgas, while I was there— Home with Isaac in a Shower. Received and partly answered a Letter from R. Rush— Read the Practical Planter. Chapter 8. Section 3. his new method of rearing Oak— His first instruction is to provide shelter Scots firs and Larches two years old to be planted, four feet from each other, four thousand to an Acre— To grow from four to seven years till four feet high, when they will shelter every thing lower than themselves— The acorns should be planted in patches two feet square, notched round with a spade; trenched a foot deep, throwing out all large Stones. The patches ten feet distance from each other or 500 to a scots acre—one spade full of slaked lime to be put upon each patch—dig it in leveling the ground, and plant five Acorns on each patch, one at the centre, and four at the four Corners—all acorns that sink in water. Cover them one inch deep with earth. Last week in March, or beginning of April— Two years after take up all the supernumerary seedlings, leaving one Oak to each patch— Thin the Oaks at five years old, and take away all overshadowing Nurses— Section 4. Account of experiments illustrative of this method of raising Oaks— These experiments were made from 1821. to 1825. with Acorns and transplanted Seedlings, and in beds limed and unlimed. The acorns in limed beds were the most thrifty— Nothing is more prejudicial to the growth of trees in general than much exposure Section 5. Succession crops of Oak, and recovering young sickly trees— When the Nurses are all cut down, the 500 Oaks to an Acre should be thinn’d down to 100— When Oaks are cut down care should be taken to leave the stumps or Stools in such order that they may produce new shoots: which two or three years after should be thinn’d to four or six shoots for each Stool— Pruning should be performed once every two years— Shoots from Oak-Stools trained for timber are called wavers. More than one stem or bole to each Stool should not be encouraged— Oak coppice requires shelter as much as the Seedlings; as much as it should be left standing as is necessary for that purpose— To recover unthrifty Oaks they should be headed down, between January and March to within one inch of the ground. Hide bound trees should have their bark slit up and down and along the principal branches— Lime is salutary to revive all deciduous trees.
17. IV. Friday— Fog— Cleared away— Scorching Sun.

Mrs Adams’s Silk-worms begin to spin— Price Greenleaf was here, part of the Morning— He brought two seedlings up, self-sown from the tree which they call a Juniper, in the road near his fathers house— I planted many of the berries, last autumn; and Seedlings from several of them have come up— I transplanted the only Stone Pine remaining of all those which had come up, from the seeds given me by Genl. Dearborn. Set it out in the Garden— My Seedlings are now suffering the ravages of Caterpillars and Rose-bugs; and the smothering of weeds— Slug worms are preying upon the Pear and Cherry trees— The Sweet-gum, Bass, and willow Oak are making their appearance. The Railway wild Strawberry Vines grow like weeds but without blossoming. The Rose-bug has nipped off
the new shoot from my grey-Oak, as the beetle-bug had nipp’d the leader before— Ambrosia, Sorrel, dog-weed and Skunk weed and purslain and wire grass, form but one detachment of my mortal foes, and my Seedlings come up in clusters so that most of them must be transplanted if they live. My Oats are prostrated by the Rain— Practical Planter. Chapter 9. Plants proper for Underwood and their Culture— Mountain Ash— Berries to be sown when gathered from the Trees— Birch-Seeds to be sown in April— The Lilac, to be planted from November to March; the plants two or three feet high when removed from the Nursery— Laburnum, Sweet-Briar Hawthorn, Holly, Juniper, Yew— Ivy, Periwinkle, Woodbine, and many others are recommended, besides the Oak Hazel, Wild Raspberry and Bramble— This Chapter is of no use to us who leave the forest to produce its own Underwood— Chapter 10. Succession Crops of Wood— To plant underwood 12 or 15 years before the wood is intended to be cut down; and train the Shoots from the Stools of old trees. Chapter 11. Account of Sir Henry Steuart’s Method of giving immediate effect to wood; that is of transplanting large Trees— The practical directions are 1. Selection of Subjects for removal. 2. Preparation of the soil for their reception— 3. Preparation of the Trees previous to removal. 4. Taking up and transportation of the Trees. 5. Planting of them in their new Situations. 6. After-management— Sir Henry Steuart never props or supports a tree after removal— He has not had one blown down in the course of 30 years, and he loses by death not more than one in from forty to forty-five— Yet I cannot believe that his large transplanted trees will be long lived— I was so much dissatisfied with my draught of a discourse for the 4th. of July, that I began writing it over again— Finished Letter to R. Rush.
18. IV. Saturday— Sun rose 4.27. Solstice.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— The Sun came out again, in disqualifying heat— Morning visit from President Quincy. He is satisfied with the Condition of the College— I spoke to him about my Son John’s degree; he said those of the Class who had been deprived of their degrees might have them for asking— He further said he had not been able to find any record of my donations or those of my father to the University— And that the attempt to turn Dr Holmes out of the board of Overseers, was a whim of James T. Austin’s— This afternoon I bathed and swam at the Creek with Charles and Isaac H. Adams— Exanimating state of the Atmosphere— Mosquitos Multitudinous. Revising my Discourse for the 4th. of July— Received a Letter from W. C. Greenleaf— Read the Practical Planter, Chapter 12. Hints for giving quick effect to wood, in the Pleasure grounds of Gentlemen’s Seats and Villa’s— That is of raising trees for ornament round a house, in a very short time— 1. To plant trees of quick growth— Poplars, Willows, Birch, Mountain Ash— Laburnum, Willows and Poplars rise to 25 or 30 feet in 10 or 12 years— Birch to 15 or 20.— 2. To plant none but choice and thrifty trees— None that have stood more than four years in the Nursery line. Oaks should never be transplanted— 3. Preparation of ground. In planting with a view to profit, let the ground remain in its original state, or nearly so, to avoid both expense, and deteriorating the quality of the wood, which in many species of Trees will happen if their growth be greatly accelerated by artificial means— But in planting for Ornament, plough trench and manure— Ashes, Lime, Street dung and mixing of Soils— The Trees should be planted at any time between November and March. Regularity of distance not material. Oak— Elm— Ash 30 feet from each other; but less, according to the depth of the Soil. Straight lines should be avoided, except on the sides of Avenues. Rows give easy admittance to the wind; an evil of the first magnitude— Trees of different kinds should be intermixed, with attention to the different shades of foliage— The shape and bearing of the Trees is worthy of regard—and
above all things keep the Plantation clear of Cattle, Sheep, Nurses and Children, weeds and Schoolboys— For five or six years there should be five or six hoeings every Summer. Dry weather should be chosen for hoeing, and stirring the ground. The trees must not be touched. Pruning should be gradual and sparing— Thinning occasional.
19. IV:40. Sunday.

Heard Mr Horace Alger of Chelsea, a Classmate of my Son Charles. His morning text was from Psalm 139.3. “Thou compassest my path, and my lying down, and art acquainted with all my ways.” That of the afternoon was from Luke 6.38.— “For with the same measure that ye mete withal, it shall be measured to you again.” They were very well written discourses—and delivered with propriety; but in the cold or at least temperate manner of the Cambridge School— Towards Sunset I bathed and swam at the Creek with Charles, and on returning found Coll. Josiah Quincy junr at our house—an Evening visit— We had the mere outskirts of a very heavy thunder shower from the North— The intervals of the day were occupied with the revisal of my discourse for the 4th. of July— Why is it that I feel more anxiety and more apprehension of failure on this occasion than I ever did in youth, when success was important to my standing in the world, and to the hopes of a long anticipated futurity upon Earth? Success or failure is now of little consequence to me, who have and can have but a few days to live— I fear the exhibition of faculties in decay— I fear a severity of judgment of the hearers, and yet more of after readers— I experienced this on my second 4th. of July Oration delivered at Washington ten years since at the Meridian of my Life— I shall now assail Passions and Prejudices as earnestly as then, deeming it now as I deem’d it then my duty—but I cannot now flatter myself that what I shall say will be received even with so much indulgence— I intended to have been short; but I have written more than the length of any Oration heretofore delivered by me, my subject spreads upon me as I proceed, and I find myself unwilling to abridge— The Style of my first draught is so plain, dry, and unadorned that it would lull the auditory to Sleep— In revising, I am endeavouring to put what Doctor Waterhouse used to call the plums in the pudding; but they are few and more relishing to myself than they will be to others— I copied and enlarged industriously, this day.
20. IV. Monday— Sun rose 4.27.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I bathed and swam with Isaac H. Adams at eight this Morning— Green headed flies audacious and tormenting. Mosquitos the same— Excessively addicted to animal food, and blood thirstier than wolves or Tygers— There has been already more Summer-heat than in the whole of the last Season or of the year before, and the multiplication of Insects has been proportional to the heat— Mr John Holmes one of the Senators in Congress from the State of Maine, with his wife; their daughter and her husband Mr Goodenow called here this afternoon, on their return from a visit to Mr Holmes’s Relations in the County of Plymouth— I occupied the day in revising the discourse for the 4th. of July. Milton supposed his powers of poetical composition were depressed by a cold Climate. Mine of prose writing are impaired by heat— I made this day some additions, and should have made more curtailments— Visited twice my Garden and Nursery; but having forbidden myself to go into them before dinner, I am now compelled to make my visit to them short and fruitless— The Seedlings have now generally ceased to come up, and some of them almost daily perish—
21. IV. Tuesday.

I gave my Son Charles a Letter of Attorney to transfer fifty Shares of New-England Insurance Company Stock as collateral security for a Note to the American Insurance Company in Boston, upon a loan of five thousand dollars for six Months at four and a half per Cent a year. The Note signed by me, and the Letter of Attorney Charles took to Boston, made the transfer, and received the money, which he deposited in the Branch Bank to the credit of my Son John whom I have authorized to draw for that amount to take up the Note to the Union Bank at Georgetown, which will be payable on the 26th. of this Month— This business was negotiated by Degrand to whom a Commission of 1/4 of one per Cent was paid— I received from my Son John a Letter of the 16th. with a note to the Union Bank at Georgetown to be signed instead of that payable on the 26th. but he had not received my Letter authorising him to draw for the money on the Branch Bank at Boston. I bathed and swam at the Creek with Isaac at ten, and the rest of the morning was busy with my revisal— The day was showery with distant Thunder and oppressively sultry— After dinner I finished reading Cruickshank’s Practical Planter— Chapter 13. upon the properties and uses of timber, enumerates successively all the forest trees and specifies the uses to which each of them is usually appropriated— There are twenty kinds— Alder, Ash, Balm of Gilead, Beech, Birch, Chesnut, Elm, Fir, Hazel, Hawthorn, Holly, Laburnum, Larch, Lime, Oak, Pine, Plane, Poplar, Spruce and Willow— Of several of these there are numerous varieties, and they do not include the Maples Tulip Trees, Locusts or Walnuts of all which we have many.— There is an Appendix to the Book, containing Remarks upon draining and fencing; and Tables of the prices of forest-trees, and of Evergreen and flowering shrubs— The measurement of Timber, and shewing the number of trees that can be planted upon an Acre. On the whole the book has given me much information concerning the plantation of forest trees, but has demonstrated to me that all I have done hitherto upon that project has been waste of time and of labour. To take five years of preparation to provide a shelter for my Acorns, would bring me to the probable termination of my Life, and there is no one to come after me who would pursue my undertaking with that Spirit which would be essential to its success— I must resign the hope of raising a forest at Mount Wollaston, and be prepared to see all the trees which have come up so well, successively perish— Of the Orchard there is yet some hope.
22. IV. Wednesday.

Bathed at the Creek and swam, with Isaac H. Adams at ten this Morning— This afternoon we had a visit from Professor Farrar of Cambridge and Mrs Farrar, whom we knew in England, and afterwards saw at Washington as Miss Rotch— They are proposing a voyage to Europe for the Professor’s health, which is delicate, and he asked me for a Letter of Introduction to the Duke of Sussex as President of the Royal Society, which I promised him— My brother’s daughter Elizabeth dined and spent the day here, and Mr Gourgas was here in the Evening— I was engaged all day upon the revisal of my lengthening discourse— Towards Evening I went with Isaac H. Adams to my grounds over the brook North of my house—plucked up six bearing Plants of Strawberry Vines, which we brought and set out in my Nursery. I took the Plants with the Strawberries upon them to be sure of having bearers— Nothing on Earth ever spread more luxuriantly
than the six roots which I transplanted from near the Railway last October, into the Garden— They are rapidly spreading over the whole bed where they were set out; but they have not blossomed, and I am strongly suspicious will prove no better than barren weeds, which I shall have more trouble to eradicate than I have had to set them out. The straw which I some time since laid down to protect the seedling fruit trees from the Sun, has stifled almost all of them— I have taken most of it away to save those yet remaining alive— Farrar hoed up the weeds in the Nursery; and with the weeds uprooted several of the seedling trees— I have one self planted Shag bark, come up under my tree in the Garden. I took up also beyond the brook a Maple yearling tree and set it out in the Garden— The four Strawberry vines, which I plucked up over the hills and set out in the garden, are putting forth new leaves— I sowed in one of the glass Tumblers some white Strawberry Seeds.
23. IV. Thursday.

North-East rain all the morning and part of the afternoon— Charles did not go to Boston— I settled with Isaac Farrar for his Rent to the first of last April— His reason for cutting down a beautiful, large, wild Cherry tree over the Hill was that he wanted fire-wood, and there was none to be bought at the wharf— My remedy for this and other losses and disappointments is Patience— I continued to work upon the revisal of my proposed discourse— Took a short walk in the Evening as far as the Temple, and returned— In the Garden I found a new Shagbark walnut up in the Summer house Cellar— The other Plants were drooping with the Rain— The Seedlings vanishing one by one— Every one of the old Peach Trees is date— Two or three which were just coming into bearing are dying— Other Peach trees in this Neighbourhood are in little better condition; yet the cause of their decay is unknown— A few days since I found one Morning the ground all round the Peach trees strewed with their leaves which had fallen from them in the Night— Yet it had been calm— One and the same cause had operated upon them all— But that cause was a mystery of Nature. My Oats or Oat grass are prostrated by the Rain— They had been so before and had partly risen again— Of ten thousand seeds and Stones, I certainly planted not less last Summer and Autumn in the Garden and Nursery, less than five hundred have come up; and those in such Clusters, that most of them choak one another. My expedients for saving them from the Sun, have killed more than they have preserved— I once heard Governor Pownall say that he had spent his life in avoiding to acquire habits— I have often thought that a man should guard himself against all propensities— I have found this however as impossible as to make my Oak Trees grow up straight— They will take bents by nature— They will receive biasses from external pressure— It is almost as difficult to educate a Tree, as a child.
24. IV. Friday— Sun rose 4:27. St. John Baptist.

Charles went to Boston and returned— Jonathan Bass was here and said his Son Lewis wished to rent the barn near the house occupied by Joseph Hardwick— I finished the revised copy of my proposed Address for the 4th. of July; which is tediously long, and contains much controversial matter— There was a time when I should have said it all with very little concern or none— But as men grow old the judgments of the world upon them and their works grow more severe— More is expected from them, less allowances are made for them. The world and Fortune favour the young. Why do I
linger upon the Stage?— Walk alone to Mount Wollaston, and partly round the border of my new Orchard— The Orchard itself is in tolerable and promising Order— The border is over run with grass and weeds from four to five feet high. There have come up, several hundreds of Oaks, Chesnuts and Walnuts, from four to nine inches high, almost all flourishing, and sheltered from the Sun, and from Insects, by the grass and weeds which surround them— This shelter is so essential to them, that I found several of the Seedlings from around which we had plucked up the grass and weeds, now killed by the Sun, and none others— This is perfectly conformable to the case mentioned in Cruickshank’s practical Planter, of a Plantation of Oaks in a lot which had been covered with furze— The furze had been grubbed up, to plant the Acorns on five sixths of the ground— In the hurry of work it had been left standing on one sixth. At the end of nine or ten years the Oaks on the ground where the furze had been left standing were fewer than where the ground had been left bare; but they had grown three times more—because, says he they had been protected from winds and frosts at the first outset—he should have added also, from the Sun, and from Insects— My seedlings at Mount Wollaston, are far more advanced than in the garden and Nursery which I have kept so assiduously weeded. Whether however this will answer so well for fruit trees—Apples, pears, plums and peaches may be doubted— From the Mount I walked to my brother’s— He and his wife returned this Morning from Medford. George Beale with Miss Otis, who lives at his father’s were there— George Dawes and his wife soon came in. Hull came home with me— I read two papers in the Horticultural Transactions Vol. 1. one by John Wilmot, very strongly disapproving the practice recently introduced of budding or grafting trees within a few inches of the ground— Because in gardens, by additional manure, the wild stock soon gets wholly covered; decays and perishes— And because the bearing stem suffers vitally by accidental injuries, which the wild stock would bear with little injury— The other paper is T. A. Knight’s Theory of Vegetation; illustrated by the culture of the Melon.
25. IV. Saturday— Sun rose 4.27.

Morning visit from Nathaniel Amory, who left with me a Pensacola Gazette, containing a Speech of Joseph M. White, the Delegate of the Territory in Congress, at a Public Dinner given him in that City— He had then, it is said, just been re-elected, though with a majority of only 45 votes. His Speech is complimentary to me, and to my Administration—and severe, upon what he calls the late Administration; especially upon the Ex-Secretary of the Navy: Branch. I read this morning my proposed Discourse for the 4th. of July, and it took me an hour and a half— Very distressing; for I know not where to abridge; and the Patience of the Auditory will never hold out for that length of Time— Wrote to my Son John, and visited my garden and Nursery after dinner, and again in the Evening. I had a seedling which came up in the Keen Earthen Pot N. 1— The Stem rose as much as three Inches above the surface of the ground— The Seed-leaves, and the first pair proceeding from them were well developed, but had a pale and sickly look. I attempted to remove it, and all the Earth in the Pot around it to the Garden, but failed. The Plant came out alone— All the earth round its root, falling away— I nevertheless did set it out— I have not yet succeeded in transplanting one seedling— I found one chesnut seedling up in the bed; which must have been planted on the 13th. of May; from those which I had kept in sand over winter— I had concluded they were all mouldy, and that none of them would come up— I had planted at the same time a row of walnuts, but none of them have come up— We had this day the first Raspberries— After Sunset I walked to Mr
Quincy’s gate, and after returning read several papers in the Horticultural Transactions Vol. 1— The only one from which profit might be derived is by T. A. Knight, upon a new method of grafting—page 239— Fitting the severed tap-root of one seedling tree to the Scion from another.
26. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney in the Morning from John 18.38. “Pilate saith unto him, What is truth.” And in the afternoon, from Job 14.14. “If a man die, shall he live again?” In both these discourses, Mr Whitney gave some of his own peculiar opinions, and in that of the afternoon inveighed vehemently against Fanny Wright an English female Atheist who has been delivering Lectures in the principal cities of the United States, against Slavery, Marriage and Christianity. She has every where gained numerous Proselytes, and there is a party scattered all over the Country, who call themselves the working men’s Party; but who are generally called by others Fanny Wright’s Party— Fanny makes no pretension to believe in a future State; nor even in the existence of a God; but she has an inveterate aversion to Slavery of all kinds. To African Slavery—Matrimonial Slavery—Religious Slavery— She declaims against them all, and never wants an Auditory— There is a Religious Sect rapidly growing in this part of the Country denominated Universalists who approach very nearly to the doctrines of Fanny, but they profess to be Christians— They suppose the Soul and body to perish together, but that the Soul at the judgment day will revive or be created afresh, to enjoy eternal happiness— And particularly that there will be no future State of punishment— This is a compound of Atheism, and Superstition well suited to the inconsistencies and absurdities incident to the reasoning faculties of men; and the Sect is spreading marvellously— They have had preachers here, for these two years, and have taken from Mr Whitney, about one third of his Parishioners. They have now the project of building a Church, though with Slender means to incur the expence, and still less for supporting a Pastor— Mr Whitney himself inclines to believe the ultimate Salvation and happiness of all mankind—but he believes a state of retribution, and that vice and crimes here will be punished hereafter.— The question of Pilate; and the question of Job furnish therefore objects of interesting enquiry to Mr Whitney— My brother was here this Evening— I visited my garden and Nursery— The Seedlings of my last Summer and Autumn Plantations, have totally ceased coming up— Certainly not one in ten have appeared, and of these it is doubtful whether one in ten will live— I have however Oaks, Chesnuts, Shagbarks, Pignuts, Apples, Pears, Peaches, Plums, Apricots, Strangers, Honey Locusts and two or three unknown, upon whose destinies I fear I shall watch till I see them all die— I read over again my discourse prepared for the fourth of July and marked about one third of it to be struck out.
27. IV. Monday— Sun rose 4:28.

Charles and his wife went to Boston, and dined, and returned early this Evening— I went at Noon to the Meeting house; and read the part which I purpose to deliver of my discourse prepared for the fourth of July, and which I found I could bring within the compass of an hour— I shall not attempt committing it to Memory. It would absorb
too much time— We had afternoon visits from Commodore and Mrs Morris, and from Mr John Bailey— I read to Mr Bailey my recent Correspondence with Mr Rush, and lent him the copy of Rush’s Letter to Edward Ingersoll— Mr Bailey wishes to obtain the appointment of professor of Moral Philosophy, at a new Institution for Education now getting up at New-York; and has been advised to procure a Letter of Recommendation to Mr Gallatin for that purpose, which he requested, and I promised— Both Mr Bailey and Commodore Morris spoke of the last incidents attending the dissolution of General Jackson’s Unit Cabinet— In the Telegraph of Friday the 17th. there was an Editorial Article, containing the following words— “It is proved that the families of the Secretaries of the Treasury, and of the Navy, and of the Attorney General refused to associate with her (Eaton’s wife) on the same Evening Eaton wrote a note to S. D. Ingham[”]—misquoting this paragraph as if it had said “the Secretary of the Treasury; of the Secretary of the Navy, and of the Attorney General, refused to associate with her”—and call it a Remark of his (Eaton’s) wife— He then says the publication appears in a paper which professes to be friendly to Ingham, and that it is brought forth under his immediate eye— He desires to know, whether he sanctions or will disavow it, and says the relation they have sustained to each other authorizes him to demand an immediate answer— Ingham answers on the 18th that he is unable to ascertain from Eaton’s note whether it is the publication or the fact which he asks him if he has sanctioned or will disavow— If the first; the demand is too absurd to merit an answer— If the last, he might find authority for the same fact in a Philadelphia Paper of about the first of April, as friendly to Eaton, as the Telegraph might be to Ingham. He adds that Eaton must be not a little deranged to imagine that any blustering of his would induce Ingham to disavow what all the Inhabitants of the City know, and perhaps half the People of the United States believe to be true— Eaton replies by a challenge and calls Ingham’s answer impudent and insolent— The 19th. was Sunday— Ingham answers Eaton’s challenge on Monday, the 20th. and says that Eaton’s brother in Law Dr Randolph, intruded himself into Ingham’s room with threats of personal violence— That he Ingham understands perfectly the part he Eaton is made to play in the farce now acting before the American People— That he is not to be intimidated by threats or provoked by abuse to any act inconsistent with the pity and contempt which Eaton’s condition and conduct inspire— Eaton closes the correspondence by a note in which he introduces a retort of imputation upon Ingham’s wife— Eaton had ceased his functions as Secretary of War on the 17th. and Dr Randolph assumed the duties as Acting Secretary on the 18th— Ingham ceased acting as Secretary of the Treasury on the 20th. and was to have left Washington on the 21st— On that day the correspondence between him and Eaton was published in the Telegraph—and on the same evening Ingham wrote a Letter to the President affirming that he had been way laid that day, both at the Treasury, and till a late hour in the Streets near his lodgings, by Eaton, Dr Randolph, W. B. Lewis, second Auditor, and also a brother in Law of Eaton’s, John Campbell the Treasurer, and T. L. Smith Register of the Treasury, for the purpose of Assassination— The President received this Letter on the 22d. and sent immediately to Ingham to ask an interview with him, but he had left the City— The President wrote a Letter to Campbell, Smith, Randolph and Lewis, enclosing Ingham’s Letter, and enquiring if they had any and what agency in Ingham’s difficulty— Randolph’s answer was ambiguous and evasive— The rest most explicitly deny the charges of Ingham, and declare they had no agency or concern whatever in the attack of Eaton upon Ingham— There is a further rumour that Eaton pursued
Ingham on his way to Baltimore, but did not overtake him— Eaton’s Letters, as if to console him for his failure to break Ingham’s head, break Priscian’s without mercy. In my garden I found a new Walnut just up in a Corner bed North-east of the Summer house Cellar.
28 IV:30. Tuesday.

George Veazie, Carpenter was here, and gave me a loose estimate of the repairs, required by my Tenant Joseph Hardwick, in the house at the foot of Penn’s hill— He said it would take forty thousand Shingles to new Roof my two barns here. Mrs Quincy junr. paid the Ladies a morning visit, and two young men, Jones and Blount, of North Carolina, brought me a Letter of Introduction from President Quincy— Jones is a Student at the Law School in Cambridge— Blount a member of the Bar in North-Carolina— I received two Letters from my Son John, and several Newspapers containing particulars of the Brawl, between the late Secretaries of the Treasury and of War— There is a Letter from Eaton to Blair the Editor of the Globe Newspaper dated and published on the 23d. instt. totally disclaiming all intention of assassinating Ingham, but acknowledging that he had challenged him to fight, and on his refusal, had sought him to make the proper application to his superficial sensibilities, as he had no others. He declares his regret that he had made any allusion to Ingham’s wife; apologizing for it, for his irritated and indignant feelings, and declaring that he had no intention or idea, that his note containing the imputation would come before the public—but he does not retract it— There is also the Correspondence between John M’Pherson Berrien, late Attorney General, and the President, relating to Berrien’s Resignation— Berrien was absent in Georgia, when the Resignations of the other Members of the Cabinet took place— His Letter of Resignation is dated at Washington the 15th. instt: very courteous in manner, and handsomely written— He explains why he had not tendered his resignation, when he first saw the President’s communication to the Secretary of the Treasury announcing his determination to organize anew his Cabinet. He had not the reasons for resigning alledged by the Secretaries of War and of State and says he was totally ignorant of any want of harmony in the Cabinet, which either had or ought to have impeded the operations of the Administration; and that he resigns his Office simply in obedience to the President’s Will— The President’s answer, dated the same day, accepts his resignation, and though also courteously expressed says that he had felt himself bound in duty to change his Cabinet in Justice to those who had been alike invited to maintain near him the Relation of confidential advisers— And because the harmony in feeling necessary to an efficient administration, had failed in a considerable degree to mark the course of this— There is a second Letter from Berrien, dated the 22d. announcing that the arrangements necessary to put the office of Attorney General in a condition for the reception of his Successor, and stating that misrepresentations in the newspaper made it proper that the Correspondence should be published— The President’s answer on the same day consents to the publication. On the point of harmony in the Administration, the Correspondents are at issue about as direct as they could be; but Berrien is the only member of the Cabinet who has gone out of Office with dignity. He has
also treated the Laws of Grammar with some respect. [symbols] Keen [symbols] N. 1— [symbols] 4 [symbols] Book box N. 1. [symbols] 4 Juglans amara [symbols]
29. IV:30. Wednesday.

Showery Morning— William Spear was here, and spoke of my Lots of Salt-Marsh lands which are to be mowed and have not been leased— Also of the Pine-wood, which he is carting for me from the lots— George Veazie came with a final estimate of repairs for the house occupied by Joseph Hardwick—about 140 dollars. Thomas and Daniel Greenleaf were here in the Evening; and spoke of the arrangements for the 4th. of July— They shewed me a List of Toasts which they had prepared; and upon which they asked for any observations which I might be disposed to make and requested me also to add to them any other toasts which I might chuse to propose— I remarked upon one of their Toasts, and requested them to omit one, in honour of myself; observing that I disliked the practice of toasting a man to his face— They said the usage of toasting the Orator of the day was so universal that it could not well be omitted— I then requested that the toast might be postponed until after I shall have withdrawn from the Hall— They said it was proposed, that the procession should go from the Town-Hall, first to Mr Whitney’s— Then round by Mr Potter’s, to take them up, and then come to my house— I thought this procession would be too long— I urged that the Toasts should avoid as much as possible all controversial Sentiment; and therefore that a compliment to the harmony of my Administration, which they had introduced into the Toasts, should be omitted, as containing an indirect reproof of the present Times.— I said I should in my own discourse which I feared would be an hour long carefully avoid all offensive allusion to the present Administration, the main scope of it being an argument against the South-Carolinian doctrine of nullification— It was probable from present appearances, that the Successors to the last Administration would do justice to themselves; and I felt no inclination to assist them in the performance of the Task— I propose to confer with these gentlemen again, before the day, which I am expecting; with an anxiety and dejection of Spirit, almost incredible to myself, and of which I am ashamed— I walked to my brothers— Met his wife, his daughter Elizabeth and his son Joseph in a Chaise; and afterwards overtook him with G. W. Beale walking— Returning from his House with his Son Isaac, I met Mr Marston, who told me that he was coming to-morrow with an Episcopal Clergyman from North-Carolina; who wished an introduction to me, and who would also be a beggar for a contribution in behalf of the Inhabitants of Fayetteville, which place has recently been almost destroyed by fire— I read before dinner a few pages of my father’s Journals, and towards Evening a few pages of Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of gardening— Live and learn says the Adage—but at my time of life is it possible to learn any thing?— They say Cato, learnt Greek after he was sixty— I doubt if he learnt it well— Wrote to my son John— [symbols] Two more honey Locusts [symbols] N. 3— Digging to plant Plum and Althaea Seedlings I struck upon two pignuts planted 13 May, both of which had taken root. I had even forgotten where I had planted them— A runner is going out from the Strawberry plant, which I brought from over the Hill— Thimble berries ripening.
30. IV:30. Thursday.

Mr Marston and Mr Potter came with the Revd. Mr Buxton, Minister of the Episcopal Church at Fayetteville, recently burnt down— Mr Buxton, solicits subscriptions to rebuild the Church, and is well satisfied with his success, though diminished by the general subscriptions for the
sufferers by that fire. The town was almost totally destroyed. The contributions throughout the Country have been very liberal— Alpheus Spear came and settled for Rent of the Mount Wollaston farm to this day— After dinner I walked to the Temple, and read my Discourse for the 4th. of July, which took me one hour— I omitted about one third, of what I had written— Saw Edward Miller at French’s Tavern— Returning home, I met my wife, and Charles’s, and rode with them to Braintree— Stopp’d at Solomon Thayer’s— He now calls his unknown grain wheat; but it appears to be neither wheat, nor Oats, nor Oat grass— He shewed me some flour ground from the kernel: Says that horses and fowls prefer it to any other grain: that he sold nine quarts of it last year for four dollars a quart— That it will produce a hundred bushels to an Acre; and that he is going on Saturday, by appointment, to meet the agricultural Society at Boston, to exhibit the grain to them, and confer with them concerning it— I asked him to call at my house on his way, and look at my grain growing from his seed, which he said he would. Mine is taller than his, and more mature, but has been prostrated by the Rain— He has also raised Silkworms and has some white Mulberry trees. After returning home I called at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s and told him that to shorten the procession next Monday, I would readily meet them at Mr Whitney’s house— He thought it would be better for Mr Whitney and Mr Potter, to call at mine: so that the procession might call, and take us all up there— I said either arrangement would be equally agreeable to me— I borrowed his List of Toasts to look them over— In the garden and Nursery I found several walnut seedlings just piercing the ground— There are now three under my old walnut tree of 1804— I have been obliged to remove all the Straw, which had been laid to preserve my seedling fruit trees from the Sun— The Straw itself having killed two thirds of the Plants. Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of Gardening says that by the last of June the Seedlings are safe from the ardent gaze of the Sun— I see that all Transplantation is extremely dangerous to trees, and a long draw back upon their growth.

Day. Same as last month— I have adhered to the practice of keeping my chamber till after dinner, but have not made profitable use of my time— The composition of a discourse for the fourth of July, and writing it twice over has engaged much of it; and of the remainder, the greater part has been wasted. I repine at the dispensations of Providence, and am neither duly sensible of the blessings I enjoy, nor watchful to improve them for the good of my fellow creatures— My own health though constantly drooping is better than I have a right to expect—that of my family has been this Month unusually good— My comforts are numberless, but my heart is not duly thankful— The prospect forward is oppressive; but the deepest of my afflictions is the comparison of the age I have attained with the nothing I have done for mankind, and the insatiable longing to do something with the conscious shame that it will never be done— I dare no longer even pray for aid from another source—
